div1.p: Kean writes about the campaign against yellow fever.

div1.head: Article: Reed, Gorgas and Yellow Fever, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 7, 1924
div1.opener:
Pub. in N. Y. Times Ap. 17/24
Sent first to Mr Hendrick, Editor of the
World's Work-
7 April 1924.
div1.p:
In June 1902 President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University gave
to Major Walter Reed the honorary degree of M.A. with the citation, “he gave
to man control over that dreadful plague, yellow fever”. This is the in-
scription on Reed's tombstone in Arlington Cemetery and its truth has not been
challenged until now. Therefore the friends of Reed and Gorgas and persons
interested in the history of medicine have been surprised recently to see what
was the crowning accomplishment of Reed's life, the demonstration that the
Stegomyia mosquito was the infecting agent of yellow fever and the only one,
claimed for another and that other, Gorgas.

In a very clever and entertaining article in a current magazine,
“Yellow Fever meets its Master”, by Marie Doughty Gorgas and Burton J.
Hendrick, occurs the statement, “Even when Reed had completed his work,
Gorgas's position was still one of extreme caution. That the Stegomyia
mosquito could transmit the disease was unassailably proved; but was this
the only way in which it could be conveyed? Was it even the ordinary way?
That, Gorgas held, had not been demonstrated----------. In the next few
months, however, it was clearly to be shown that the Stegomyia, and the
Stegomyia only, was the infecting agent and the man who was to make this
clear for all time was Gorgas himself”.

This statement arrived at its conclusion by ignoring the admirable
and convincing series of experiments of Reed with infected bedding and cloth-
ing and with the discharges from patients, which made it as clear as the
noonday that the Stegomyia was the ordinary and the only normal way of trans-
mitting the disease. If these experiments did not convince Gorgas, neither
could conviction be drawn from his own experience in the next few months,
1.
for he continued, until the middle of August 1901, the disinfection of bedding
and clothing of yellow fever cases which Reed had shown to be unnecessary.
This claim is introductory to a statement in the beginning of the fourth chapter
which is equally erroneous. It is that Reed's demonstration was a mere academic
performance which Reed himself saw no practical way of applying. The intimation
clearly is that the methods of warfare against the mosquito were unknown until
devised and put into operation by Gorgas about February 15, 1901. This is,
however, far from being the fact. The writings of the distinguished Entimolo-
gist, L. O. Howard, had made the use of kerosene to control mosquito breeding
well known to Army Sanitarians. Under the stimulation of Reed's influence the
Chief Surgeon of the Department of Western Cuba had, on October 15, 1900, three
months before the acceptance by Gorgas of the mosquito theory, published a
circular to medical officers calling attention to the fact that mosquitos were
known to convey malaria and filarial disease and were suspected of conveying
yellow fever also, and directing the prevention of mosquito breeding by the
use of kerosene on deposits of water. On December 21, 1900, still before the
conversion of Gorgas, General Order No.6 was issued from General Leonard Wood's
Headquarters directing, with minuteness of detail, the warfare against mosquitos.
As Gorgas began to put in practice more than two months later the procedures specified
in this order, it cannot be claimed that he was the discoverer of anything not
already known. The General Order above mentioned was published in Havard's
Military Hygiene, 2nd Edition, Wm. Wood & Co. What he did do is well stated
in a letter he wrote to Reed, dated August 26, 1901, in which he says, “I am
very happy to shine in the more humble role of being the first to put your
discovery to extensive practical application”.

The fame of Gorgas is secure in the performance of the greatest
feat of sanitary administration that the world has seen. It does not need
augmentation by claiming for him what belongs to his brilliant and unreward-
ed friend, Walter Reed.
